conclusion: Objects A and B move through the air and are placed on top of objects C, D, E, and F due to gravity.

Image 1 shows objects labeled A, B, C, D, E, and F, with A and B appearing to be in motion or about to be moved and placed on top of C, D, E, and F. The table has two fabrics: an orange one and a patterned one.
Image 2 shows objects A and B placed on top of C, D, E, and F, with the orange and patterned fabrics sagging and draped over these objects.
When objects A and B land on C, D, E, and F due to gravity, their weight causes the fabrics to deform and drape around them.
The deformation of the fabric depends on the combined weight and shape of the objects underneath.
The fabrics are flexible enough to stretch and conform to the new shapes created by the placement of A and B.
Image 3 shows the orange cloth visibly sagging and deformed, and the patterned cloth sagging and draped over the objects with visible tension in areas where it is stretched more.
The colors and patterns of the fabrics provide visual cues for how the fabrics have been displaced.

When objects A and B are placed on top of C, D, E, and F, their weight causes the fabrics to sag and drape around them, deforming and stretching to conform to the new shapes created by the combined presence of A, B, C, D, E, and F.
